metadata.synopsis:
Roles: No Compromise, At Any Cost, Bridge, Karlach
, Orpheus Path Lae'zelAll companions can fill all these roles, so the roles should not be seen as a hard stance in a debate, but the speakers to highlight the risks and options of the big decision. So player questions should remain open ended, asking for party feedback and not telling the party what they will do.

No Compromise: Why they can't be the one to transform, the risks involved, can they trust the Emperor? Some sub nodes should have different reactivity in the case they are already partial illithid, or were open to using the powers but never did

At Any Cost: Why the player needs to be the one to transform, why these decisions may be necessary, the stakes at hand

Bridge: The bridge between the two other topics, to facilitate the and direct the discussion and return the questions back to the player.

Karlach: The only one who can take the players place as the party Mind Flayer. With three companions, she replaces the bridge in most cases. Two companions she replaces the At Any Cost. Orpheus Path Lae'zel:Always in the "No Compromise" speaker slot, her only mission is to save Orpheus. If the player decides to allow Orpheus to be assimilated, she will interect with a high possibility of leaving the party and fighting the player if they refuse to change their mind.

This dialog is about the avatar and what they should do, but the decision is not made here as it's possible the player can change their mind when they return to gameplay or talk to the Emperor. This is a discussion of their available options, their feelings towards them, and why the player needs to be the one to transform (exception being Karlach). Their is a risk the player may feel sour towards their team for the perceived cowardice, as almost all of them are not willing to transform. This dialog will need to sell why the player is the hero of this story.

156.speaker: Player
156.text: Sacrifice Orpheus, sacrifice the githyanki people to an eternity of Vlaakith's tyranny.

113.speaker: Player
113.text: You will take the hammer, and you will smash the bonds that trap Gith's blessed spawn.

211.speaker: Player
211.text: Orpheus will lead the charge against the Netherbrain. First, the Grand Design will be thwarted; next, the Comet will raze the Undying Queen!

131.speaker: Player
131.text: If we're to defeat the brain, transformation may be the better option.

30.speaker: Player
30.text: Do what you will. Do not expect me to stand quietly by.

161.speaker: Player
161.text: Becoming a mind flayer seems unthinkable, after all we've done to avoid it.

54.speaker: Player
54.text: Unthinkable, and unnecessary. I cannot have been clearer. You know what must be done.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: We could give the stones to the Emperor. Better to trust a mind flayer than become one.

126.speaker: Player
126.text: Freeing Orpheus may very well be the best option here.

166.speaker: Player
166.text: We have no means of freeing Orpheus. What else can we do?

176.speaker: Player
176.text: Today, the illithid falls and the Comet flies free. You either stand with me, or against me.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: Enough talk. It's time to act.

36.speaker: Player
36.text: The Emperor might be right, but we're not out of options yet.
36.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: We have an option: Me

189.speaker: Player
189.text: Let me transform. I'm... I'm not long for this world. I can feel it.
189.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish the Karlach optionNodeContext: The weight behind this is Karlach knows she's gonna die, and that's why she's offering.

148.speaker: Player
148.text: There'll be no risk in the Emperor controlling me - it's the perfect solution.
148.context: NodeContext: A little sad, but resolute.

132.speaker: Player
132.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Direct focus to player. What do you think we should do?NodeContext: Growing resolve.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: This should be my sacrifice to make. Not yours.

22.speaker: Player
22.text: Soldier, my heart feels like a live grenade - gonna blow any minute. You still have a life to live. I don't.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: Let me do this for you. For me. Please, darling. I want to.
1.context: NodeContext: Her resolve cracks slightly on the 'darling,' an aside to the player if they're in love.

207.speaker: Player
207.text: If this is the end for me, let me be the motherfucker who saved the world.
207.context: NodeContext: A return to her swag.

12.speaker: Player
12.text: All right. If this is what you really want, all I can say is thank you.

11.speaker: Player
11.context: NodeContext: Full of Bond-like charm. She's just agreed to take on the ultimate sacrifice, and she's doing it with style.

158.speaker: Player
158.text: If anyone was gonna be able to pull off a few tentacles, it was going to be me. Let's do this.

190.speaker: Player
190.text: I can't, Karlach. I'm sorry. I want it to be me, not you.

162.speaker: Player
162.text: I know you. I know you know your own mind. If this is what you want, then all I can say is give 'em Hell, soldier.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: I won't have to look at you much longer anyway, so I'm really getting the good end of the deal.
112.context: NodeContext: Cheekily. Saying she's dying soon so she won't have to see the player be an ugly mind flayer for long. Macabre humor, but she means it affectionately.

205.speaker: Player
205.text: No - none of us is turning into a mind flayer. If that means giving them the stones, then so be it.

67.speaker: Player
67.text: We should at least free Orpheus first. There might be another solution here.

183.speaker: Player
183.text: I trust you. Do what you think is right, and I'll stand by you.

120.speaker: Player
120.text: But if you change your mind, just say so. I'm here. And I'm ready for whatever comes next.

106.speaker: Player
106.text: If this is the end for you, you should go out as yourself, not a mind flayer.

175.speaker: Player
175.text: I'd rather be a mind flayer than have to watch you become one. You still get to live. Do it as you.

89.speaker: Player
89.text: Are you sure this is what you want?

167.speaker: Player
167.text: I've never been more sure of anything. This heart inside me is about to blow. Doesn't matter which body it takes out with it, right?

202.speaker: Player
202.context: NodeContext: Her resolve cracks slightly on the 'darling,' an aside to the player if they're in love.

49.speaker: Player
49.text: |The Emperor could be right, but that doesn't mean we're out of options.|
49.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: The Emperor might be right and but hint Karlach might be the best option

43.speaker: Player
43.text: Let me do it. Let me transform. I don't have much time left. I can feel it. And once I'm gone, the Emperor won't be able to control me.
43.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish the Karlach option

111.speaker: Player
111.text: Make the next moments count. They cannot be undone.

107.speaker: Player
107.text: This should be my sacrifice Karlach, not yours.

104.speaker: Player
104.text: Soldier, my heart feels like a live grenade - gonna blow any minute. You still have a life to live. I don't.

29.speaker: Player
29.text: Let me do this for you. For me. Please, darling. I want to.

110.speaker: Player
110.text: You heard what the Emperor said. Even if we kill it, we still need a mind flayer to be able to use the stones.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: Willing? I'm eager. I'd rather be a mind flayer than have to watch you become one. You still get to live. Do it as you.

90.speaker: Player
90.text: This heart inside me is about to blow. Doesn't matter which body it takes out with it, right?

157.speaker: Player
157.text: If this is the end for me, let me be the motherfucker who saved the world.

121.speaker: Player
121.text: All right. If this is what you really want, all I can say is thank you.

58.speaker: Player
58.context: NodeContext: Full of Bond-like charm. She's just agreed to take on the ultimate sacrifice, and she's doing it with style.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: |Let's hope it doesn't come to that Lae'zel.|

127.speaker: Player
127.text: I can't, Karlach. I'm sorry. I want it to be me, not you.

143.speaker: Player
143.text: I know you. I know you know your own mind. If this is what you want, then all I can say is give 'em Hell, soldier.

65.speaker: Player
65.text: No, Karlach, I won't let you make this sacrifice. If that means giving the stones to the Emperor, then so be it.

32.speaker: Player
32.text: I trust you. Do what you think is right, and I'll stand by you.

199.speaker: Player
199.text: But if you change your mind, just say so. I'm here. And I'm ready for whatever comes next.

34.speaker: Player
34.text: |We should at least free Orpheus before we consider all lost.|

94.speaker: Player
94.text: I'll become a mind flayer. It's our best option.

103.speaker: Player
103.text: Freeing Orpheus may very well be the best option here.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: We have no means of freeing Orpheus. What else can we do?

84.speaker: Player
84.text: Maybe it's worth freeing Orpheus instead, Lae'zel.

165.speaker: Player
165.text: We have the Orphic Hammer. We could set the prince free.

160.speaker: Player
160.text: |I trust any judgement, but I would ask that you trust me as well. We have time, let's make use of it.|

60.speaker: Player
60.text: Transformation seems unthinkable, after all we've done to avoid it.
60.context:
InternalNodeContext: Note: The two questions nodes that lead to this dialog are "I don't give a shit about Orpheus, but I want to wield the stones myself" or "So if I become illithid and assimilate Orpheus, then I can wield the stones myself?"
This means that the player has already framed an interest in transforming

108.speaker: Player
108.text: We could give the stones to the Emperor. Better to trust a mind flayer than become one.

171.speaker: Player
171.text: That's a huge risk. And we don't have to make it, if I transform.

47.speaker: Player
47.text: Enough talk. It's time to act.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: |I'd trust no one else with that kind of power.|
73.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish why the player is the hero here

209.speaker: Player
209.text: |I'd better trust our friend as a mind flayer than the Emperor, no?|
209.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Why the player/Karlach is their most trusted option to transform if they choose to do so.

85.speaker: Player
85.text: |I've been fighting the illithid powers ever since I was infected. I'm not about to embrace them and become a mind flayer.|

152.speaker: Player
152.text: |I don't trust that mind flayer one bit, but something has to be done.|

180.speaker: Player
180.text: |It burns me to say it, but I'd trust you far more as a mind flayer than the Emperor weilding the stones.|

28.speaker: Player
28.text: |But we also have the Orphic hammer. We can free Orpheus, and I'm sure he would have a better solution.|

70.speaker: Player
70.text: |There is no one else more capable. We are lucky to have another shot at this, and failure is not an option.|

24.speaker: Player
24.text: |But we should consider all our options carefully.|

23.speaker: Player
23.text: If we're to defeat the brain, transformation may be the better option.

99.speaker: Player
99.text: |I would trust you more with the stones, but it must be getting something out of this for it to so willingly offer this solution.|

9.speaker: Player
9.text: We could give the stones to the Emperor. Better to trust a mind flayer than become one.

96.speaker: Player
96.text: |Then we very well may be trading one foul beast for another. Those stones have great power, and I'm sure the Emperor would twist it as much as it twists its words.|

181.speaker: Player
181.text: Freeing Orpheus may very well be the best option here.

123.speaker: Player
123.text: |Indeed, if he decideds to not cut us down for what happened back at intermezzo.|

17.speaker: Player
17.text: Enough talk. It's time to act.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: |I trust you'll make the right choice.|

125.speaker: Player
125.text: This is no offer - it is sacrilege! Ignore the ghaik - kill him if you must - but I will not witness the fall of Gith's blessed son!

56.speaker: Player
56.text: The Emperor could be right, but that doesn't mean we're out of options.
56.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: The Emperor might be right and but hint Karlach might be the best option

3.speaker: Player
3.text: |I'm not pleased either, but what if the Emperor is right? What if the only way to do the right thing is to make this sacrifice?|
3.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: What other options are there? The Emperor might be right?

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Sacrifice Orpheus, sacrifice the githyanki people to an eternity of Vlaakith's tyranny. I won't accept it.

129.speaker: Player
129.text: I get that, but there has to be another option here.
129.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Support previous node, but direct to other options

77.speaker: Player
77.text: The answer is in our very sight, bound by astral chains. Deny the ghaik, and free the Prince of the Comet. He will lead us to sure glory.

16.speaker: Player
16.text: The answer is in our very sight, bound by astral chains. Deny the ghaik, and free the Prince of the Comet. He will lead us to sure glory.

147.speaker: Player
147.text: Let me do it. Let me transform. I don't have much time left. I can feel it. And once I'm gone, the Emperor won't be able to control me.
147.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish the Karlach option

81.speaker: Player
81.text: |Bickering amongst each other is not going to do us any good. We are only this far because of you, and this decision is ultimately up to you.|
81.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Direct focus to player. What do you think we should do?

150.speaker: Player
150.text: This should be my sacrifice to make, Karlach. Not yours.

206.speaker: Player
206.text: Soldier, my heart feels like a live grenade - gonna blow any minute. You still have a life to live. I don't.

114.speaker: Player
114.text: If this is the end for you, you should go out as yourself, not a mind flayer.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: I'd rather be a mind flayer than have to watch you become one. You still get to live. Do it as you.

187.speaker: Player
187.text: This heart inside me is about to blow. Doesn't matter which body it takes out with it, right?

144.speaker: Player
144.text: Let me do this for you. For me. Please, darling. I want to.

138.speaker: Player
138.text: |Why hesitate if she is so willing?|

170.speaker: Player
170.text: A pointless exercise to even discuss it. If there must be a sacrifice, let us start with the ghaik.

186.speaker: Player
186.text: You heard what the Emperor said. Even if we kill it we still need a mind flayer to use the stones.

100.speaker: Player
100.text: |We still don't know what that mind flayer schemes.|
100.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: We still don't know what the Emperor is really planning

86.speaker: Player
86.text: If this is the end for me, let me be the motherfucker who saved the world.

194.speaker: Player
194.text: All right. If this is what you really want, all I can say is thank you.

6.speaker: Player
6.context: NodeContext: Full of Bond-like charm. She's just agreed to take on the ultimate sacrifice, and she's doing it with style.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: If anyone was gonna be able to pull off a few tentacles, it was going to be me. Let's do this.

145.speaker: Player
145.text: Assimilate Gith's faithful son, and I will cut you down, Karlach. This is my promise.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: It'd be an honour to die at your hand, Lae'zel. Just wait 'til this is over to run me through, all right?

55.speaker: Player
55.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Still some doubt, even with Karlach's condition

153.speaker: Player
153.text: |I beleive she's our best chance, with the added benifit of not needing to cut her down otherwise.|
153.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Reaction to previous node doubt

25.speaker: Player
25.text: I can't, Karlach. I'm sorry. I want it to be me, not you.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: I know you. I know you know your own mind. If this is what you want, then all I can say is give 'em Hell, soldier.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: No - none of us is turning into a mind flayer. If that means giving them the stones, then so be it.

159.speaker: Player
159.text: I trust you. Do what you think is right, and I'll stand by you.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: But if you change your mind, just say so. I'm here. And I'm ready for whatever comes next.

133.speaker: Player
133.text: We should at least free Orpheus first. There might be another solution here.

115.speaker: Player
115.text: I'll become a mind flayer. It's our best option.

74.speaker: Player
74.text: |If you really think it's the right thing to do.|

122.speaker: Player
122.text: |We are so close to the end. If that's what you feel is best, I'll follow you.|
122.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Affirming player decision

173.speaker: Player
173.text: Transformation seems unthinkable, after all we've done to avoid it.
173.context:
InternalNodeContext: Note: The two questions nodes that lead to this dialog are "I don't give a shit about Orpheus, but I want to wield the stones myself" or "So if I become illithid and assimilate Orpheus, then I can wield the stones myself?"
This means that the player has already framed an interest in transforming

44.speaker: Player
44.text: |I think we are past the point of good feelings. What we choose here will have to be whichever feels the least terrible, unfortunately.|
44.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Avoiding the transform option may be very difficult, if not impossible

204.speaker: Player
204.text: It's just going to give us the stones, is it? Where's the catch?
204.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Frustration at the situation or towards the previous node

198.speaker: Player
198.text: |I'd say we finish our bickering and cut the Emperor down. It's plan failed once, why would it work this time?|
198.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Suggest killing the Emperor, frustrated by his games

63.speaker: Player
63.text: We could give the stones to the Emperor. Better to trust a mind flayer than become one.

98.speaker: Player
98.text: Give the ghaik those stones, and githyanki freedom dies with the Prince of the Comet. I will not stand for it.

92.speaker: Player
92.text: |And give it complete control of the brain? Sounds short sighted.|
92.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Extreme doubt the Emperor would do good in possession of the stones

200.speaker: Player
200.text: |We give it what it wants and none of us transform?|
200.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: May not be such a bad thing

14.speaker: Player
14.text: I will not let you damn my people to eternal slavery. Damn the ghaik, and damn your continued allegiance to it.

87.speaker: Player
87.text: |Complete control of the most powerful being in Faerun?|
87.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish doubt in the Emperor

5.speaker: Player
5.text: Freeing Orpheus may very well be the best option here.

135.speaker: Player
135.text: The right choice, the only choice. The Prince of the Comet shall not just blaze a path for the githyanki - but for all who oppose the Grand Design.

178.speaker: Player
178.text: You are my obsession, the one who has parted grey clouds to show me yellow sun. Now, I need you to be the Source of Salvation.

184.speaker: Player
184.text: We have no means of freeing Orpheus. What else can we do?

35.speaker: Player
35.text: We have no means because you refused to seek them. Orpheus is my people's last hope. Let him be destroyed, and you will know an even crueler death than his.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: |We have the rare luxury of time here. Let's carefully consider all our options.|
109.context: InternalNodeContext: Node Subject: We will figure it out

155.speaker: Player
155.text: We have no means because you refused to seek them. Orpheus is my people's last hope. Let him be destroyed, and you will know an even crueler death than his.

195.speaker: Player
195.text: Maybe it's worth freeing Orpheus instead, Lae'zel.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I know my queen's mission. And I know neither storm nor sundering will keep me from it.

102.speaker: Player
102.text: We have the Orphic Hammer. We could set the prince free.

93.speaker: Player
93.text: And he would know freedom for but a moment before he fell to my weapon.

101.speaker: Player
101.text: |It's hard to be certain, but he's our best bet.|
101.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Better to at least try

33.speaker: Player
33.text: Enough talk. It's time to act.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: All right. It's agreed. All we can do now is hope it's right.
40.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Hope for the best

192.speaker: Player
192.text: Know this, without doubt: I will not hesitate do defend Orpheus if I must, even from you.

134.speaker: Player
134.text: Know this, without doubt: I will not hesitate do defend Orpheus if I must, even from you.

88.speaker: Player
88.text: Know this, without doubt: I will not hesitate do my queen's bidding. Should that mean your death and mine, so be it.

4.speaker: Player
4.text: |Any choice is better than no choice at this point.|
4.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Affirming player choice

64.speaker: Player
64.text: Assimilate Orpheus, and you sin against the Mother to all githyanki. I will not let you take him.

45.speaker: Player
45.text: |We worked hard enough to get that Orphic Hammer. We should at least consider putting it to use.|
45.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subjest: Point player to potentially using the hammer they brought with them

136.speaker: Player
136.text: |We don't have many other options outside taking it's head.|
136.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish why the player is the hero here

128.speaker: Player
128.text: |You do whatever you want, but I'm not becoming a mind flayer.|
128.context: InternalNodeContext: Node subject: Re-establish why companion will not transform

31.speaker: Player
31.text: We hold the means to the Prince's release and his killing. You cannot be beholden to this abominable ghaik.

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Make the next moments count. They cannot be undone.

203.speaker: Player
203.text: The illithid threat needs to be destroyed from root to stem - I will not condone anyone volunteering for ceremorphosis.
203.context:
InternalNodeContext: Node subject: I am not turning into a mind flayer. 

Only the avatar can transform, this is going to be a question on the back of the players mind as they go through this dialog. Each character may have their own personal reasons not to be willing, but it needs to be a strong one since they may already be partially transformed. This can be used to further emphasis why the player is the hero of this story
